subject: Re: [junit] a test framework to codify levelizaton?

messageBody:
Vlad Roubtsov wrote:

> On any but the trivial projects the number of
> testcases quickly exceeds 100-200+. It usually takes a
> noticeable time to run them all.

Can you quantify this? GSBase, for example, runs tests at approximately
100/second, and that's my usual performance goal for tests. On my most
recent project, I separated tests that required expensive, external
resources (there were about 10) from tests than ran entirely in memory
(there were about 400). The in-memory tests ran in about 6 seconds.

Is this "noticeable" by your standards? I'd merely like some extra context.

> It is also less
> efficient to do so because it ignores the idea of
> levelization (from John Lakos' underappreciated book
> "Large Scale C++ Software Design"). In incremental dev
> mode it would be more efficient to execute only the
> testcases that correspond to the product package(s)
> that's just changed (and the dependency closure
> thereof) AND execute them in increasing level numbers
> (reverse package dependency topological order).

This is a great idea, however, computing the complete dependency closure
is awfully tricky. For most algorithms that attempt to do this, I can
load a class through reflection and use it, breaking the algorithm's
assertion that it correctly computes the runtime dependency closure. I'm
not saying it's impossible -- although it might be -- but I am doubtful
that any existing tool does this adequately and could be integrated into
Eclipse, for example.

> A tool/framework that enforces test (sub)suite
> execution in increasing level numbers would seem like
> the next evolutionary step after naive TDD. Does
> anyone know of such a tool? The testcase->app package
> assignment could be done by simply placing testcases
> in the relevant package (common practice already
> anyway) or by something like Java 1.5 metadata
> tagging.

I'm not aware of anything, but if it exists, the C#/.NET world would be
a likely first place to look. They've had metadata tagging longer than
Java folks have.

> There are tools to analyze existing package
> dependencies, but I am not aware of a test framework
> to actually relate that data to testcase execution
> ordering.

Those tools likely only analyze compile-time (structural) dependecies,
and as I wrote above, it would be all too easy to exhibit a runtime
dependency that such an analyzer would miss. The result is that runtime
behavior might change without the analyzer knowing to run all the
appropriate tests.

I am admittedly shaky on the theory, and welcome being proven wrong, but
I have this vague notion that I'm right.
